description: Validates mentions of securities/values within fund presentations (Section 4.2). Ensures compliance with investment recommendation restrictions and proper disclosure of portfolio holdings.
regulatory_framework: French AMF regulations on investment recommendations (MAR regulation)

rules.rule_name: No Direct or Indirect Investment Recommendations
rules.rule_text: No direct or indirect investment recommendations
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not contain any direct or indirect investment recommendations regarding specific securities. This includes any statement that could be construed as advice to buy, sell, or hold a particular security. An investment recommendation is defined under MAR regulation as information recommending or suggesting an investment strategy regarding one or several financial instruments.
rules.purpose: Prevents unauthorized investment advice and protects clients from potential conflicts of interest
rules.severity_definition: Absolute prohibition - constitutes regulatory breach under MAR
rules.consequences: Document rejection, potential AMF sanctions, legal liability for unauthorized investment advice

cross_references.description: Defines investment recommendations and disclosure requirements

rules.validation_method: Scan for language suggesting investment action or recommendation
violation_examples: We recommend investing in Company X
This stock is a good buy opportunity
Investors should consider adding this security
We suggest accumulating shares of Company Y
This is an attractive investment at current levels

rules.rule_text: Do not indicate if a security is undervalued / overvalued / fairly valued
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not provide valuation opinions about specific securities. This includes any assessment of whether a security's current market price is below, above, or at fair value. Such statements constitute implicit investment recommendations by suggesting the security may rise (if undervalued) or fall (if overvalued).
rules.purpose: Prevents implicit investment recommendations through valuation opinions
rules.consequences: Document rejection, regulatory breach, potential AMF investigation
rules.validation_method: Detect valuation language and price-to-value comparisons
violation_examples: Company X is trading below its intrinsic value
We believe the stock is undervalued at current prices
The security appears overpriced relative to fundamentals
Fair value is estimated at €50, current price €40
The market has not yet recognized the company's true value

rules.rule_text: Do not suggest an investment strategy
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not suggest specific investment strategies related to individual securities or portfolio positions. This includes timing recommendations (when to buy/sell), positioning advice (overweight/underweight), or tactical allocation suggestions. General fund strategy descriptions are allowed, but not actionable strategy suggestions for specific securities.
rules.purpose: Prevents fund materials from becoming investment advisory documents
rules.consequences: Document rejection, regulatory violation, potential licensing issues
rules.validation_method: Identify strategy-suggesting language and tactical recommendations
violation_examples: Investors should overweight technology stocks now
Consider reducing exposure to financials
Good time to accumulate defensive positions
We suggest rotating into value stocks
Tactical opportunity to increase energy allocation
common_errors: Disguising strategy suggestions as market commentary

rules.rule_text: Do not compare securities to each other
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not compare individual securities to each other in ways that suggest relative investment merit. Direct comparisons of performance, valuation metrics, growth prospects, or quality between specific securities can constitute implicit recommendations by suggesting one is superior to another.
rules.purpose: Prevents implicit recommendations through relative comparisons
rules.severity_definition: Significant violation - implies preference for one security over another
rules.consequences: Document rejection, must remove comparative language
rules.validation_method: Detect comparative statements between specific securities
violation_examples: Company A offers better growth prospects than Company B
Stock X is cheaper than Stock Y on a P/E basis
We prefer Company C over Company D for exposure to this sector
Security A has outperformed Security B over the past year
Company X is a better quality business than Company Y

rules.rule_name: No Repeated Mentions of Same Security
rules.rule_text: Do not cite the same security multiple times
rules.detailed_description: A specific security should not be mentioned multiple times throughout a fund presentation. Repeated mentions can give undue prominence to a particular holding and may suggest implicit recommendation or excessive focus on one position. If a security must be mentioned for illustration, it should appear only once.
rules.purpose: Prevents over-emphasis on specific holdings that could constitute implicit recommendation
rules.consequences: Document revision required, reduce mentions to maximum one instance
rules.validation_method: Count occurrences of specific security names throughout document
violation_examples: Mentioning 'Apple Inc.' in portfolio holdings, strategy discussion, and performance attribution
Citing 'TotalEnergies' multiple times across different slides
Repeated references to the same company in various contexts

allowed_cases: Single mention in portfolio holdings list
One illustrative example in strategy description
Reference in legal disclaimer if necessary

common_errors: Same company mentioned in different contexts

rules.rule_text: No future projections for a security
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not include forward-looking projections, forecasts, or predictions about individual securities' future performance, earnings, growth, or price movements. This includes both quantitative projections (price targets, earnings estimates) and qualitative forward-looking statements (expected to grow, likely to outperform).
rules.purpose: Prevents speculative statements that could mislead investors and constitute recommendations
rules.consequences: Document rejection, regulatory breach, potential AMF sanctions
rules.validation_method: Detect future-oriented language about specific securities
violation_examples: We expect Company X to grow earnings by 15% next year
Stock Y is projected to reach €100 per share
This security will likely outperform the market
Company Z should benefit from industry tailwinds
Target price of €50 within 12 months

rules.rule_name: No Opinions on Current or Future Value
rules.rule_text: No opinion on the current/future value of an instrument
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not express opinions about the current or future value of specific financial instruments. This prohibition covers both explicit value opinions ('this stock is worth €X') and implicit opinions through qualitative assessments ('strong value proposition', 'compelling valuation'). Factual reporting of current market prices is allowed.
rules.purpose: Prevents subjective value assessments that constitute investment recommendations
rules.severity_definition: Absolute prohibition - value opinions imply recommendations
rules.validation_method: Identify value assessment language and opinions
violation_examples: In our view, this stock offers excellent value
We believe the company is worth significantly more
The security's true value is not reflected in the current price
Compelling valuation at current levels
Attractive risk-reward profile

rules.rule_text: Do not say buy, sell, reinforce a security
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must never use action verbs that instruct or suggest investors to buy, sell, hold, accumulate, reduce, or otherwise transact in specific securities. These are the most explicit forms of investment recommendations and are strictly prohibited. Even conditional or hedged versions of these instructions are not allowed.
rules.purpose: Prevents explicit investment recommendations through action verbs
rules.severity_definition: Most severe violation - explicit recommendation language
rules.consequences: Immediate document rejection, serious regulatory breach, potential AMF penalties
rules.validation_method: Detect action verbs related to trading and investment decisions
violation_examples: Buy shares of Company X
Sell holdings in Stock Y
Accumulate positions in this security
Reduce exposure to Company Z
Hold this stock for long-term gains
Reinforce positions in sector leaders

rules.rule_text: Do not provide specific analysis on a security
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not include detailed analytical commentary focused on individual securities. This includes fundamental analysis (financial metrics, business quality, competitive advantages), technical analysis (chart patterns, price trends), or any detailed examination that could inform investment decisions about specific securities. General portfolio characteristics and broad sector commentary remain allowed.
rules.purpose: Prevents fund materials from becoming research reports with implied recommendations
rules.severity_definition: Significant violation - detailed analysis implies recommendation
rules.consequences: Document rejection, must remove specific security analysis
rules.validation_method: Identify detailed analytical content about individual securities
violation_examples: Company X has strong cash flow generation with ROIC of 20%
Stock Y shows improving margins and market share gains
Technical analysis indicates strong support at €45
The company's competitive moat provides pricing power
Balance sheet analysis reveals hidden value in assets
prohibited_content: Detailed financial metrics (P/E, EV/EBITDA, ROE, margins)
common_errors: Including detailed metrics in portfolio holdings descriptions

rules.rule_text: No favorable/unfavorable opinion on an issuer or narrow sector
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations must not express favorable or unfavorable opinions about specific issuers (companies) or narrow/restricted sectors. Opinions indicating preference, quality assessment, or investment merit constitute implicit recommendations. Broad sector commentary (technology, healthcare, financials) without specific opinions is allowed, but narrow subsectors with limited issuers are treated like individual securities.
rules.purpose: Prevents implicit recommendations through qualitative assessments
rules.validation_method: Detect opinion language about issuers and narrow sectors
violation_examples: Company X is a high-quality operator in its sector
We like the management team at Company Y
This is a well-managed company with strong fundamentals
European EV battery manufacturers face challenges
French luxury conglomerates are well-positioned
common_errors: Sector opinions that are too narrow

rules.rule_text: The use of phrases such as 'in our view', 'in our opinion', even in conditional form, can constitute an investment recommendation depending on context
rules.detailed_description: Phrases that introduce subjective opinions or views can transform factual statements into investment recommendations depending on the context. Even when used conditionally or with hedging language, phrases like 'in our view', 'we believe', 'in our opinion' can be interpreted as recommendations if they relate to investment merit, valuation, or future prospects of specific securities.
rules.purpose: Clarifies that opinion language creates recommendation risk regardless of grammatical structure
rules.consequences: Document revision required, remove opinion phrases or reformulate factually
rules.validation_method: Flag opinion phrases and assess context for recommendation risk
violation_examples: In our view, this company offers strong growth potential
We believe the stock is attractively valued
In our opinion, this sector will outperform
According to us, this represents a good opportunity
It is our assessment that the security is undervalued
common_errors: Assuming conditional language removes recommendation risk
Using opinion phrases for securities commentary

rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations may discuss broad market trends, themes, and developments without restriction. This includes commentary on overall market conditions, sector trends affecting multiple securities, macroeconomic factors, and investment themes. Such discussions must remain at a general level and not focus on specific securities or narrow groups of issuers.
rules.purpose: Clarifies scope of permitted market commentary
rules.consequences: None - this content is explicitly allowed
rules.validation_method: Verify market trend discussion remains general and broad
permitted_examples: The European equity market has experienced volatility
Technology sector benefiting from digital transformation trends
Emerging markets showing recovery momentum
Energy transition driving renewable energy growth
Consumer behavior shifting toward e-commerce

do_not_cross_into: Specific security recommendations within the trend

rules.rule_text: References to exchange rates, interest rates, commodities, macroeconomic indicators (without mention of a specific instrument or issuer) (allowed)
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations may freely reference and discuss macroeconomic variables including exchange rates, interest rates, commodity prices, and economic indicators, provided these references do not link to specific financial instruments or issuers. Discussion can include expectations and views on these macro variables as they affect broad markets, not individual securities.
rules.purpose: Permits necessary macro context for investment strategy without creating recommendation risk
rules.consequences: None - this content is explicitly allowed
rules.validation_method: Verify macro references remain general without instrument-specific connections
permitted_examples: EUR/USD exchange rate has strengthened by 5%
Central banks raising interest rates to combat inflation
Oil prices increased due to supply constraints
GDP growth projections revised upward
Inflation rates declining across developed markets
permitted_topics: Commodity price trends (oil, gold, metals, agriculture)

boundaries.allowed: Rising interest rates may pressure bond valuations
boundaries.not_allowed: We recommend buying inflation-linked bond X to protect against inflation

rules.rule_text: Discussing general sectors (caution if sector is narrow) (allowed)
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations may discuss general, broad sectors (technology, healthcare, financials, consumer goods, etc.) including trends, outlook, and positioning. However, caution is required if the sector is narrow or restricted to a small number of issuers, as this approaches specific issuer commentary. Broad sectors with many participants are safe for discussion.
rules.purpose: Permits necessary sector context while preventing circumvention through narrow sector focus
rules.severity_definition: Informational - describes permitted content with caution note
rules.consequences: None if sector is sufficiently broad; violation if sector is too narrow
rules.validation_method: Verify sector breadth - many issuers indicates general sector, few issuers indicates narrow
permitted_examples: Technology sector benefiting from cloud adoption
Healthcare sector supported by aging demographics
Financial services navigating regulatory changes
Consumer discretionary impacted by spending trends
Industrial sector exposed to manufacturing cycles

rules.rule_text: Providing factual information (e.g., recent events, public announcements) (allowed)
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations may include factual, objective information about companies, securities, or markets. This includes recent events, public announcements, historical data, and verifiable facts that are publicly available. The key distinction is that information must be purely factual without interpretation, opinion, or forward-looking implications that could constitute recommendations.
rules.purpose: Permits necessary factual context for portfolio holdings and strategy explanation
rules.consequences: None - factual information is explicitly allowed
rules.validation_method: Verify information is factual, public, and without opinion or forward-looking implications
permitted_examples: Company X announced a dividend of €2 per share
The company completed its acquisition of Company Y in Q3
Stock Z is listed on the Paris Stock Exchange
The firm reported revenues of €5 billion in fiscal year 2024
The company operates in 15 countries across Europe

boundaries.factual_allowed: Company X reported 10% revenue growth in 2024
boundaries.opinion_not_allowed: Company X's strong 10% revenue growth demonstrates excellent execution
boundaries.forward_looking_not_allowed: Company X is expected to grow revenues by 10% in 2025

rules.rule_text: Mentioning portfolio holdings + past performance with appropriate disclaimers (allowed)
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations may disclose current or past portfolio holdings along with their historical performance, provided appropriate disclaimers are included. Required disclaimers include 'past performance is not indicative of future results' and 'capital at risk'. Holdings should be presented factually without commentary suggesting investment merit, and performance data must be historical only.
rules.purpose: Permits transparency about fund composition and track record with proper risk disclosure
rules.severity_definition: Informational - describes permitted content with required disclaimers
rules.consequences: None if disclaimers present; violation if disclaimers missing

cross_references.description: General rules for performance disclosure and disclaimers

rules.validation_method: Verify holdings disclosure includes required disclaimers and remains factual
permitted_examples: Top 10 holdings as of [date]: [list with percentages]
Portfolio allocation by sector: Technology 25%, Healthcare 20%...
Security X contributed +2.5% to fund performance in 2024
Geographic distribution: France 40%, Germany 25%, Italy 15%...
required_disclaimers: Past performance is not indicative of future results
Capital at risk / investment value may fluctuate
Holdings subject to change without notice
permitted_formats: Portfolio characteristics (avg market cap, P/E, etc.)

boundaries.allowed: Company X represented 5% of portfolio at month-end and contributed +1.2% to returns
boundaries.not_allowed: Company X is our largest holding because we believe it will outperform

rules.rule_text: Providing an illustrative example of an issuer or security, without projection or price estimate (allowed)
rules.detailed_description: Fund presentations may use specific securities or issuers as illustrative examples to explain investment strategy, portfolio construction, or market dynamics. Examples must be purely illustrative without projections, price estimates, valuations, or any language suggesting investment merit. The example should serve only to clarify a concept or demonstrate a process.
rules.purpose: Permits practical illustration of strategy without creating recommendation risk
rules.severity_definition: Informational - describes permitted content with restrictions
rules.consequences: None if purely illustrative; violation if example includes projection/valuation
rules.validation_method: Verify example is illustrative only, without forward-looking or value judgments
permitted_examples: For example, Company X operates in the renewable energy sector, illustrating our thematic approach
A typical holding might be a company like Y, with strong balance sheet and international presence
To illustrate sector diversification, we hold securities across technology (e.g., Company A), healthcare (e.g., Company B)...
An example of our ESG screening: Company Z meets our environmental criteria through...
prohibited_in_examples: Future projections for the example company
Language implying preference for the example

boundaries.allowed: For example, Company X in the technology sector illustrates our focus on innovation
boundaries.not_allowed: Company X is an example of an undervalued technology stock we favor

rules.rule_text: During interviews: portfolio managers must limit themselves to publicly known facts; may comment on historical data, but no opinion on current/future value or price
rules.detailed_description: When portfolio managers participate in interviews, media appearances, podcasts, or other public communications, they must adhere to strict guidelines. Commentary must be limited to publicly available information and historical facts. Portfolio managers may discuss past performance and factual holdings information but must not express opinions on current or future security values, prices, or investment merit. All statements must avoid creating investment recommendations.
rules.purpose: Extends securities mention rules to oral communications and media appearances
rules.severity_definition: Significant violation - oral communications have wide reach and regulatory scrutiny
rules.consequences: Reputational risk, potential AMF investigation, requirement for corrective public statement
rules.validation_method: Review interview transcripts or recordings for compliance with securities mention restrictions
interview_best_practices: Focus on process, not specific securities
Redirect security-specific questions to general themes
Avoid opinion phrases ('in our view', 'we believe')

example_responses.safe: Our fund focuses on quality companies with strong fundamentals. We look at factors like balance sheet strength and competitive positioning.
example_responses.unsafe: We really like Company X right now - it's undervalued and we expect strong returns from this position.

investment_recommendation_definition.definition: Information recommending or suggesting an investment strategy, explicitly or implicitly, concerning one or several financial instruments or the issuers of financial instruments, including any opinion as to the present or future value or price of such instruments
key_elements: Recommendation or suggestion of investment strategy
Concerns specific financial instruments or issuers
Covers opinions on present or future value/price

allowed_content_categories.market_commentary: Broad market trends, sector themes, geographic markets
allowed_content_categories.macro_references: Interest rates, exchange rates, commodities, economic indicators
allowed_content_categories.factual_information: Public announcements, historical events, verifiable facts
allowed_content_categories.portfolio_disclosure: Holdings lists, sector allocation, geographic distribution
allowed_content_categories.illustrative_examples: Examples to explain strategy without projections
allowed_content_categories.historical_performance: Past returns and attribution with disclaimers

allowed_vs_prohibited.allowed_sector: Technology sector benefiting from digital transformation
allowed_vs_prohibited.prohibited_narrow_sector: European luxury automakers are well-positioned (only 3-4 companies)
allowed_vs_prohibited.prohibited_opinion: Company X's strong growth demonstrates excellent management
allowed_vs_prohibited.prohibited_recommendation: We hold Company Y because it's undervalued

critical.definition: Explicit investment recommendations, action verbs, valuations, projections

major.definition: Implicit recommendations, opinion language, comparative analysis
examples: In our view, Company X offers value

minor.definition: Borderline language that could be misinterpreted

compliance_workflow.step_1: Identify all security mentions in document
compliance_workflow.step_2: Classify each mention (name only, with analysis, with opinion, etc.)
compliance_workflow.step_5: Count repeated mentions of same security
compliance_workflow.step_7: Flag violations with severity and remediation

use_cases: Reviewing fund presentations for recommendation language
Checking marketing materials for securities mentions
Training investment teams on communication restrictions
common_queries: Can I mention specific stocks in the presentation?
How do I discuss portfolio holdings without recommendations?
What disclaimers are required for performance?
Can portfolio managers give opinions in interviews?
What language is prohibited for securities?
How many times can I mention the same stock?
